::: {style="color: white; padding: 5rem 2rem; margin-bottom: 3rem; font-family: 'Georgia', serif; font-size: 3rem; font-weight: 470; line-height: 1.1; margin: 0;"}
Movement & Spatial Ecology of Australian Shorebirds
:::

::: {.title-overlay style="background: linear-gradient(135deg, rgba(15,25,55,0.67), rgba(25,45,85,0.67)); color: white; padding: 3rem 2rem; text-align: center; border-radius: 12px; box-shadow: 0 4px 6px rgba(0,0,0,0.1); margin-bottom: 2rem;"}
This Research Project is conducted within the [**Center for Conservation Science**](https://www.csrg.site/our-group) by Maxime Marini (PhD candidate), Andrea S. Griffin (Associate Professor) and many other [collaborators](https://themaskou.github.io/movement_ecology_shorebirds/qmd/myphd.html).

The project aims to better understand spatial and movement ecology of Australian shorebirds, as their behaviours within and across local estuaries of the Hunter and Port Stephens. Trying to address varied questions as where and when do they move? What roles tidal and circadian cycles are playing into these movements? Where and when birds are foraging and/or roosting? Do the species share or segregate their food resources? How much the inter-tidal areas (mudflats) extents infer demographic trends?

We collected our main data-set thanks to the valuable help of the [**Hunter Birder Observer Club**](https://www.hboc.org.au/) of Newcastle, which allowed us to trap and equip birds with a band, a flag marker and a Motus Lotek Nano-tag. Blood and feathers were sampled and other bio-metrics were also taken.
:::

Therefore, the project is limited to certain amounts of bird sampling. Navigate the following documents to track these legal boundaries.
